The world class athlete and possibly the best Safety in NFL history, Sean Taylor, was shot in the leg, which severed the femoral artery and even though he was rushed to Jackson Memorial Hospital, one of the best hospitals in the US, they were unable to save him. He most likely died before ever reaching the hospital.

If the average person moves a liter of blood per minute through the femoral artery, you can imagine that a world class athlete moves even more since exercise increases the size of arteries to move oxygen to the muscle faster to remove the lactic acid output of the muscle fibers when they contract.

Basically, an athlete like Sean Taylor would probably bleed out faster than some obese middle age man with 50% clogged arteries. The one time being fat could be a positive.

The reason I know Jackson Memorial Hospital is one of the best in the US is because I had an intestinal transplant there in 2010, the only reason I’m still alive since I lost all of my intestines and the TPN that was keeping me alive was also killing me, so doctors were giving me only 18 months to live.

Every doctor said small bowel transplant were impossible. The intestines are guarded more aggressively and even have their own immune system built in. That’s because the intestines are a dirty organ and ground zero for all things infectious in the world getting into our bodies.

My wife didn’t accept this claim and continued to search, eventually finding 6 hospitals into he world that had successfully performed small bowel transplants and Jackson was one with the best survival record, tied with Pittsburgh. Since we lived in central Florida, Jackson in Miami was a no-brained.

They were able to give me a transplant that no other hospital in the world, other than 5 others, could give. There are many other crazy transplants being successfully done at Jackson, like a woman who had a uterus transplant and actually conceived a child. They do great work there, but Sean was just gone before he ever reached there.

That’s how deadly a shot to the leg can be.

Im about to intern in mortuary school. the reason eyes might be hard to keep shut usually comes when a person has been through rigor mortis. when the rigor starts to naturally break, the eyes are the first muscles to relax, which can be a good thing. But that also means decomposition begins right away so we usually embalm while the body is in rigor. (This all being said that we can't embalm a person before they go into rigor). During embalming, the tissues firm up and features are "set" so eyelids can pop open naturally. We do stuff to keep the lids down for the family though.

It isn't the burial itself so much as the other things surrounding the burial site. The land isn't allowed to go back to nature necessarily in order to remain a place for family to mourn and some physical reminder to remain. As we bury more and more people who would like those monuments, would this create problems in the future? I know that this probably isn't entirely consistent across all forms of Islam and Judaism and across all regions and cultures and all versions of natural burial, but it seems to be a visible enough practice that it has affected my perception. For every picture I see of graves overtaken by grass and wildflowers with only simple headstones, there are more complex and seemingly more permanent and manicured burials surrounded by more ornamental stones or iron fences.

Doctors try to reassure patients and families by affirming that these waves are only the reactions of a dead brain. But in reality they don’t know what they are and if the brain could take hours before dying after body death. When confronted in front of a so-called brain-dead patient, they hide the fact that often, even with no signs of consciousness and pain, the patient show brain activity! But because this activity isn’t similar to the one of a live body, they say that they are useless and that the patient is dead. These liars bother me so much that i refuse to give my organs, no knowing if i would be still alive or not. Each time i see a walk of honour, i am wondering if the patient is not conscious, even a little, and is trying to alert his family before being vivisectioned, without anesthesia. I would never say that cremation is more environmentally friendly. It's more that it harms the environment in different ways - for example, what's the fuel for the crematorium? Chances are, they're burning fossil fuels which harms the environment. However, a lot of the casket choices involve varnishes and paints that can be harmful to the ground's ecosystem and may even result in some poisoning of the ground water. There's also the embalming process which slows the decay process of the body - good for if you need to postpone the funeral so everyone can come say goodbye, but generally not needed for most funerals with open caskets as they're usually held within a few days to a week. I've heard some say that embalming fluid can poison the ground, but I'm not entirely sure that's completely accurate. From what I understand, that's more likely to depend on your choice of casket/coffin than the embalming process itself.

Personally, I think I'd like to be buried in a cheap plain box with a simple shroud - chosen for quick and easy decomposition. I also fully expect my family to completely disregard my wishes and hold a super Christian funeral with all the typical embalming and fancy casket. The fun part of being the atheist communist sheep in the conservative fundie Christian family. Oh well. I'll be dead. It's not like I'll know.
